author: Medical Author Nazneen Memon; BHMS; PGDCR Medical Reviewer Pallavi Suyog Uttekar; MD
description: A well-stocked medicine cabinet is essential for every household to treat a minor illness or injury. Learn the seven common "must have" medicines and first aid supplies to have on hand in case of emergencies.
cleaned_text: A well-stocked medicine cabinet is essential for every household to treat a minor illness or injury, such as [headache](https://www.medicinenet.com/headache/article.htm), [runny nose](https://www.medicinenet.com/runny_nose/symptoms.htm), aches and pains, and [insect bites](https://www.medicinenet.com/bug_bites_and_stings_symptoms_and_signs/symptoms.htm). These items can help ensure a healthy and safe life. Here are some suggestions of common medicines and [first aid](https://www.medicinenet.com/first_aid/article.htm) supplies that you should have on hand in case of emergencies when you cannot get to a pharmacy. [Acetaminophen](https://www.medicinenet.com/acetaminophen/article.htm) - These are [pain](https://www.medicinenet.com/pain_management/article.htm)and [fever](https://www.medicinenet.com/aches_pain_fever/article.htm)relievers that can reduce inflammation related to conditions, such as backaches and toothaches, [common cold](https://www.medicinenet.com/common_cold/article.htm), [arthritis](https://www.medicinenet.com/arthritis/article.htm), and [sprains](https://www.medicinenet.com/sprained_ankle/article.htm). These can be administered to kids and minors though you should be mindful of the age-appropriate dosages. - These are - Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory [drugs](https://www.medicinenet.com/drugs_what_you_should_know_about_your_drugs/article.htm)( [NSAIDs](https://www.medicinenet.com/nonsteroidal_antiinflammatory_drugs/article.htm)), or [Aspirin](https://www.medicinenet.com/acetylsalicylic_acid/article.htm) - They work as a [pain reliever](https://www.medicinenet.com/analgesics_antipyretics/article.htm)for adults and help decrease swelling and [pain](https://www.medicinenet.com/pain_quiz/quiz.htm)caused by inflammation. - Ibuprofen can be used to relieve pain due to various conditions, such as [headache](https://www.medicinenet.com/migraine_headaches_pictures_slideshow/article.htm), dental pain, period pain, muscle aches, or [arthritis](https://www.medicinenet.com/arthritis_symptoms_and_signs/symptoms.htm). - According to the American [Heart](https://www.medicinenet.com/heart_how_the_heart_works/article.htm)Association (AHA), crushed Aspirin helps during a [heart attack](https://www.medicinenet.com/heart_attack/article.htm). - They work as a - Decongestants or [cough](https://www.medicinenet.com/chronic_cough/article.htm)suppressants - These are available in several forms (syrups, pills) that contain pseudoephedrine or phenylephrine. [Cough](https://www.medicinenet.com/cough/symptoms.htm)expectorants (works by loosening [mucus](https://www.medicinenet.com/treating_congestion/article.htm)) and suppressants (works by controlling or reducing cough) are necessary for quick relief from incessant colds, [flu](https://www.medicinenet.com/influenza/article.htm), and cough. - Decongestants help clear a runny nose and relieve [postnasal drip](https://www.medicinenet.com/postnasal_drip_symptoms_and_signs/symptoms.htm). - Avoid using opioid-based cough suppressants. [Antihistamines](https://www.medicinenet.com/antihistamines-oral/article.htm) - Antihistamines, such as [diphenhydramine](https://www.medicinenet.com/diphenhydramine/article.htm)(sedating) and [loratadine](https://www.medicinenet.com/loratadine/article.htm)(nonsedating), help tackle runny noses, [hives](https://www.medicinenet.com/hives/article.htm), [itching](https://www.medicinenet.com/itch/article.htm), and [allergic](https://www.medicinenet.com/allergy/article.htm)reactions caused by a wide range of causes, such as [hay fever](https://www.medicinenet.com/hay_fever/article.htm), [hives](https://www.medicinenet.com/hives_urticaria_symptoms_and_signs/symptoms.htm), [conjunctivitis](https://www.medicinenet.com/pink_eye/article.htm), and allergic reactions to insect bites or stings. - Try to stock both oral antihistamines (liquid or pill) and hydrocortisone cream (a mild steroid) for topical application to treat [rashes](https://www.medicinenet.com/rash/article.htm), swelling, [itching](https://www.medicinenet.com/itch/symptoms.htm), and irritation due to as - Antacids, laxatives, antidiarrheal, oral [heartburn](https://www.medicinenet.com/heartburn_reflux/article.htm), [belching](https://www.medicinenet.com/intestinal_gas_belching_bloating_flatulence/article.htm), and stomach upset or hyperacidity. - Laxatives or [stool](https://www.medicinenet.com/stool_color_changes/article.htm)softeners, such as milk of magnesia, can soothe [stomach cramps](https://www.medicinenet.com/stomach_cramps/symptoms.htm)caused by [constipation](https://www.medicinenet.com/constipation/article.htm). - Antidiarrheal medicines, such as [loperamide](https://www.medicinenet.com/loperamide/article.htm)are used to stop frequent and liquid bowel movements due to infections caused by [viruses](https://www.medicinenet.com/viral_infections_pictures_slideshow/article.htm), bacteria, and parasites, side effects of medicines (such as antibiotics), and digestive disorders (such as coeliac disease) or [irritable bowel syndrome](https://www.medicinenet.com/irritable_bowel_syndrome_ibs/article.htm). - ORS solution restores the hydration and [electrolyte](https://www.medicinenet.com/electrolytes/article.htm)balance in the body and replaces fluids lost due to [vomiting](https://www.medicinenet.com/nausea_and_vomiting/article.htm)or [diarrhea](https://www.medicinenet.com/diarrhea/article.htm). - Vitamin and mineral [supplements](https://www.medicinenet.com/vitamins_minerals_and_nutritional_supplements/article.htm) - Lozenges - Nasal sprays - Ear drops - Medicines for [motion sickness](https://www.medicinenet.com/motion_sickness_sea_sickness_car_sickness/article.htm) - Sterile dressings or medical tapes - Skincare products, such as moisturizers and sunscreens 7 tips for using over-the-counter medicines - Always read and follow the printed directions and warnings on the packet label. - Look at the list of ingredients or contents mentioned and choose products that suit you the best and you are not allergic to. - Check the expiration date before using any product or medicines. - Store medicines in a cool, dry area. - Keep all medicines out of the reach of children. [Pregnant](https://www.medicinenet.com/pregnancy_symptoms_and_signs/symptoms.htm)and [breastfeeding](https://www.medicinenet.com/breastfeeding/article.htm)women should talk to their providers before taking any new medicines. - Older adults and children are affected by medicines differently; take special care about dosages when giving [over-the-counter](https://www.medicinenet.com/over-the-counter_products/article.htm)medicines to them. The skin turns white and loses sensation with third-degree burns. Burn treatment depends upon the burn location, total burn area, and intensity of the burn. First Aid: Why You Need a First Aid Kit and CPRFirst aid is providing medical assistance to someone a sick or injured person. The type of first aid depends on their condition. Preparedness is key to first aid, like having basic medical emergency kits in your home, car, boat, or RV. Many minor injuries may require first aid, including cuts, puncture wounds, sprains, strains, and nosebleeds. Examples of more critical first aid emergencies include heart attacks, strokes, seizures, and heatstroke. Extreme Heat EmergencyToo much heat can make you tired, sick, and woozy. WebMD guides you through these and other things heat can do to your body and what to do about it. What Is the First Aid for Seizures?Some seizures are caused by brain diseases, tumors, genetic conditions, or other illnesses or disorders that can be diagnosed (symptomatic seizures). When the cause for the seizures is unknown, they are referred to as idiopathic or cryptogenic seizures. If a person has a seizure, loosen the clothing around his/her neck and remove sharp objects around the person to prevent injury. After the seizure, lay the person on his/her side to maintain an open airway. If the seizure lasts more than five minutes or if the person cannot be awakened after the seizure, call 911. Learn common seizure triggers, including foods or medications, hormones, stress, lack of sleep, dehydration, or sensitivity to light. First Aid: Bandaging Injuries and Wounds From Head to ToeBandaging a wound like a burn, cut, or scrape requires different techniques depending on which part of the body was hurt. Ace bandages, liquid bandages, bandage wraps, waterproof bandages, elastic bandages, and other types are available to cover and protect your wound from dirt and water. First Aid: Wound Care for Cuts and ScrapesWound care treatment at home involves performing cuts and scrapes first aid including cleaning the injury and applying antibiotic ointment and a bandage. Use wound care products like adhesive bandages, hypoallergenic bandages, sprays, tape, and gauze. If cuts and scrapes don't heal, see your doctor. Heat Exhaustion (First Aid Tips)Heat exhaustion is a milder form of heat-related illness that can develop after several days of exposure to high temperatures and inadequate or unbalanced replacement fluids. Warning signs of heat exhaustion include heavy sweating, paleness, muscle cramps, tiredness, weakness, dizziness, headache, nausea or vomiting, and fainting. A person suffering from heat exhaustion should stop the activity are doing, move to a cooler environment, and rehydrate with liquids, for example, water or sports drinks. Complications of heat exhaustion are dehydration, muscle weakness, nausea, and vomiting. Heat exhaustion can progress to heat stroke (a medical emergency) if not treated.
